ElementDescription: The NDAR Global Unique Identifier (GUID) for research subject
Subject ID how it's defined in lab/project
Date on which the interview/genetic test/sampling/imaging/biospecimen was completed. MM/DD/YYYY
Age in months at the time of the interview/test/sampling/imaging.
Notes: Age is rounded to chronological month. If the research participant is 15-days-old at time of interview, the appropriate value would be 0 months. If the participant is 16-days-old, the value would be 1 month.

ElementDescription: Sex of subject at birth
Notes: M = Male; F = Female; O=Other; NR = Not reported

ElementDescription: Data file 1
type of data file 1
data file 1 category
Notes: HRV=heart rate variability daily data file per participant; Annotation=Corresponding annotation file with metadata information

ElementDescription: Date for the summary statistics
Fraction of data missing
Average actigraphy
Standard deviation of activity
Time of the peak in the 24 hour cycle; measure of the timing of overall high values recurring in each cycle
24 Hour rhythm-adjusted mean of activity movements
Measure of the extent of rhythmic change or range of activity and rest values over 24 hours
Number of epochs Cole-Kripke algorithm classifies as wake divided by data length

Number of transitions between�epochs Cole-Kripke algorithm classifies as wake and�epochs Cole-Kripke algorithm classifies as sleep divided�by data length. For example if the algorithm predicted whole day is sleep or whole day is wake then it would be 0.
Least active 5 hour period in the average 24 hour pattern.
Most active 10 hour period in the average 24 hour pattern.
Relative amplitude is derived from the normalised difference between the most active 10 hour period and least active 5 hour period in an average 24 hour pattern and indicates the quantity of activity
